snippet: Richard Grenell, a foreign policy spokesman for Mitt Romney, resigned on Tuesday after an unexpectedly messy and public dispute over his role and reputation.
abstract: Aides to Mitt Romney insist they did everything to keep Richard Grenell, gay political strategist, from resigning; on one level, his short-lived and rocky tenure with the campaign is the story of halting attempts to manage Romney's relationship with the conservative wing of the party; on another level, it is also about how a fast-growing campaign, operating under the sharp glare of a general election, failed to spot potential hazards of a high-profile appointment. Photo (M)

byline.original: By MICHAEL BARBARO, HELENE COOPER and ASHLEY PARKER; Jeff Zeleny and Richard A. Oppel Jr. contributed reporting from Washington

lead_paragraph: It was the biggest moment yet for Mitt Romney's foreign policy team: a conference call last Thursday, dialed into by dozens of news outlets from around the globe, to dissect and denounce President's Obama record on national security. But Richard Grenell, the political strategist who helped organize the call and was specifically hired to oversee such communications, was conspicuously absent, or so everyone thought.

headline.main: Romney Camp Stirred Storm Over Gay Aide
